Pre-Lecture 14 Reading Before the lecture you should read: 8.4 Confidence Intervals Based on Large Samples 8.4.1 Confidence Interval for the Population Proportion (Asymptotic Confidence Interval) 8.4.1.1 Score/Wilson Confidence Interval NOT Covering 8.4.1.2, 8.4.1.3 or 8.4.1.4

Example 8-23 Use R, either via RStudio on your own device or this online console. # These functions may be useful qnorm() library(binom) binom.confint() Solution # R Code 8.17 n <- 25 p <- 15/n # sample proportion alpha <- 0.10 # alpha level z <- qnorm(1 - alpha/2) # critical value me <- z*sqrt(p*(1 - p)/n) # margin of error CI <- p + c(-1, 1)*me CI [1] 0.4388379 0.7611621 library(binom) binom.confint(x = 15, n = 25, conf.level = 0.90, methods = "asymptotic") method x n mean lower upper asymptotic 15 25 0.6 0.4388379 0.7611621 # For full solutions see textbook/lecture slides

Example 8-25 Use R, either via RStudio on your own device or this online console. # These functions may be useful library(binom) binom.confint(x = , n = , conf.level = , methods = "asymptotic") binom.confint(x = , n = , conf.level = , methods = "wilson") prop.test(x = , n = , correct = FALSE, conf.level = )$conf Solution #(a) The Wald 95% confidence interval #R Code 8.21 n <- 40 x <- 26 p <- x/n # sample proportion passing z <- qnorm(0.975) # critical value n <- 40 CI <- p + c(-1, 1)*z*sqrt(p*(1 - p)/n) CI [1] 0.5021883 0.7978117 # Or library(binom) binom.confint(x = 26, n = 40, conf.level = 0.95, methods = "asymptotic") method x n mean lower upper asymptotic 26 40 0.65 0.5021883 0.7978117 #(b) The Wilson 95% confidence interval #R Code 8.22 prop.test(x = 26, n = 40, correct = FALSE, conf.level = 0.95)$conf [1] 0.4950588 0.7786547 attr(,"conf.level") [1] 0.95 # Or binom.confint(x = 26, n = 40, conf.level = 0.95, methods = "wilson") method x n mean lower upper wilson 26 40 0.65 0.4950588 0.7786547 # For full solutions see textbook/lecture slides

Example 8-27 Use R, either via RStudio on your own device or this online console. # These functions may be useful library(binom) binom.confint(x = , n = , conf.level = , methods = "asymptotic") Solution #(a) Construct a 95% Wald confidence interval x <- 400 n <- 2000 p <- x/n z <- qnorm(0.975) # z_{0.975} CI <- p + c(-1, 1)*z*sqrt(p*(1 - p)/n) CI [1] 0.1824695 0.2175305 # Or binom.confint(x = 400, n = 2000, conf = 0.95, methods = "asymptotic") method x n mean lower upper asymptotic 400 2000 0.2 0.1824695 0.2175305 #(b) Determine the required sample size so that the maximum margin of error is within 0.015 f <- function(x){sqrt(x*(1 - x))} # x takes place of p in f curve(expr = f, from = 0, to = 1, n = 500) n <- 0.5*0.5*1.96^2/0.015^2 ceiling(n) [1] 4269 # For full solutions see textbook/lecture slides
